Detailed Description

The Simulation Class.

This is the heart of muse. All core operation that the engine handles are done from this class. This class implaments the Singleton pattern and should NOT be used as a superclass to derive from. Also the client should not try and create an instance using the constructor. use the getSimulator() method which will return a pointer to a Simulation object. Once you have all your agents and their events in place you can get the simulation going with three easy steps. 1st - get a simulation object via the getSimulator() method. 2nd - register all your agents. 3rd - finally get the simulation stared via the start() method. To stop the simulation early just call the stop() method.

Note: refer to each method documentation for more details on the features provided.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

The dtor method.

Cleans up all mess created by muse.

Member Function Documentation

const SimulatorID* muse::Simulation::getSimulatorID (  ) 

The getSimulatorID method.

Use this method to obtain the id of the simulator you are working with. Typically in parallel simulation this will be the MPI_Rank.

Returns:
Simulator* pointer to the id of the simulator
See also:
SimulatorID

const AgentID* muse::Simulation::registerAgent ( const Agent &  agent  ) 

The registerAgent method.

Once you design and create an agent for your simulation, use this method to register the agent to the simulator. For example a client could check the SimulatorID and with a switch statement register agents to different simulators on different processes.

Parameters:
agent this is of type Agent. Agent passed in will not be modified.
Returns:
AgentID* once registered an id is automatically generated and will be globally unique.
See also:
Agent()

AgentID

const AgentContainer* muse::Simulation::getRegisteredAgents (  ) 

The getRegisteredAgents method.

When this method is invoked, it will return all agents that are registered to a given simulator. Basically returns the container all simualtion objects hold.

Returns:
AgentContainer * a pointer to a container
See also:
AgentContainer

const Simulation* muse::Simulation::getSimulator (  ) 

The getSimulator method.

The simulation class implaments a singleton pattern, then only way to access reference to the only object of type Simulation is via this method. Calling this method it will check if there is already an object created if there is, the client will receive a pointer to that object, otherwise a Simulation object is created then the client will receive a pointer to that object. The client will need this object to get the ball rolling.

Returns:
Simulation* the pointer to the Simulatin object.

void muse::Simulation::start (  ) 

The start method.

When this method is invoked the client should have all agents registered. The simulation will start.

void muse::Simulation::stop (  ) 

The stop method.

When this method is invoked the simulation will come to a big STOP. muse will go through and finalize all agents and clean up.
